facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1635 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 1635 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated May 7, 1965 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 205 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated May 7, 1965 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 205 of 1961.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court answered the referred question in the negative against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: judgment of the Calcutta High Court answering the following question referred to it in the negative and against the assessee

facts.text: Referred question: Whether the loss of Rs. 1,11,816/- suffered by the assessee on the sale of shares of Fort William Jute Company Limited was a loss that arose in its share dealing business.

anchor.surface_text: answering the following question referred to it in the negative and against the assessee Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,11,816/-

facts.text: Assessee is a public limited company carrying on business of dealing in shares and securities.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a public limited companypany. It Carries on, inter alia, business of dealing in shares and securities.

facts.text: Profits and losses from transactions in shares in ordinary course of assessee's business always treated as such.

anchor.surface_text: The profits and losses arising from transactions in shares in the ordinary companyrse of the assessees business have always been treated as profits or losses

facts.text: During assessment year 1954-55 (accounting period financial year 1953-54), assessee suffered loss of Rs. 1,11,816 on sale of 1,575 preference shares of Fort William Jute Company Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: During the assessment year 1954-55, relevant accounting period being the financial year 1953-54 the assessee suffered a loss of Rs. 1,11,816 on the sale of 1,575 preference shares

facts.text: 1,575 preference shares purchased on May 22, 1952 at Rs. 186 per share from Mugneeram Bangur Co.

anchor.surface_text: These shares were purchased on May 22, 1952 at the rate of Rs. 186 per share from Mugneeram Bangur Co.

facts.text: Shares sold on December 23, 1953 at Rs. 115 per share to Mugneeram Bangur Co.

anchor.surface_text: and were sold on December 23, 1953 at the rate of Rs. 115/- per share to the same companypany.

facts.text: Agreement entered on May 21, 1952 between Kettlewell Bullen Co. and Mugneeram Bangur Co. for sale of entire holdings of 6,920 preference shares and 600 ordinary shares at Rs. 185 pref and Rs. 400 ord.

anchor.surface_text: On May 21, 1952 an agreement was entered into between Kettlewell Bullen Co. and Mugneeram Bungur Co. according to which the entire holdings of Kettlewell Bullen Co. in the managed companypany

facts.text: Kettlewell Bullen Co. were managing agents of Fort William Jute Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Kettlewell Bullen Co. were the managing agents of Fort William Jute Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Kettlewell Bullen to resign as managing agents from July 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Kettlewell Bullen Co. would tender resignation from the office of the managing agents with effect from July 1, 1952.

facts.text: Market price of preference shares on May 21, 1952 ranged between Rs. 119 and Rs. 122 per share.

anchor.surface_text: At the time of the agreement, namely, May 21, 1952 the market price of the preference shares ranged between Rs. 119/- and Rs. 122 per share

facts.text: Assessee acquired total 1,670 preference shares from Mugneeram Bangur Co.: 1,620 on May 22, 1952 at Rs. 186/share, 50 on May 27, 1952 at Rs. 184/share.

anchor.surface_text: The total number of preference shares of Fort William Jute Company Ltd. which were acquired by the assessee from Mugnee- ram Bangur Co. was 1,670. One lot of 1,620 shares was purchased

facts.text: Assessee overdrew on bank account for acquisition of these shares.

anchor.surface_text: For the acquisition of these shares the assessee had to overdraw on its Bank account.

facts.text: Loss of Rs. 1,11,816 included in loss of Rs. 1,30,152 debited to P&L account under head loss on sale of investment.

anchor.surface_text: resulting in a loss of Rs. 1,11,816 which was included in the loss of Rs. 1,30,152/- debited to the profit and loss account under the head loss on sale of investment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected assessee's claim that loss arose in ordinary course of business, holding it was contribution to scheme of acquisition of managing agency.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the assessees claim on the ground that the shares were purchased as a companytribution to the scheme of acquisition

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal found no evidence that assessee was pawn in scheme, but held shares not acquired in course of share dealing business based on distinction in P&L account between dealer and investor transactions.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal found that there was numberevidence that the assessee had been made a pawn in the scheme of acquisition of the managing agency... From the treatment of the loss given by the assessee in its own profit and loss account

facts.text: High Court held that assessee entered transaction at bidding of Bangurs to help in scheme, not in ordinary course of business.

anchor.surface_text: Taking the overall picture the High Court felt that there companyld be only one inference that the assessee--an associate of Mugneeram Bangur Co.-had enttred into the transaction relating to preference shares

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's answer against assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question must, therefore, be in the negative and against the assessee and it was rightly so returned by the High Court. The appeal fails and it is dismissed

facts.text: Market rate of preference shares constant at Rs. 119 between April 16, 1952 and May 21, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: The market rate of the preference shares remained companystant at the figure of Rs. 119/- between April 16, 1952 and May 21, 1952.

facts.text: Out of four directors of assessee, two were Bangurs.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was companynected with the Bangurs only to the extent that out of its four Directors two of the Directors were Bangurs.

facts.text: Transactions in Fort William Jute shares stood apart: involved nearly Rs. 3,00,000, acquired and sold in one lot to/from same party Mugneeram Bangur Co.

anchor.surface_text: the transaction in Fort William Jute Co. shares involved the payment of nearly Rs. 3,00,000. These shares were acquired in one lot from Mugneeram Bangur Co. and sold back to the same companycern

facts.text: Bangur Brothers Ltd. appointed managing agents from July 1, 1952 for 10 years.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Bangut Bros., were appointed as the managing agents of Fort William Jute Company for a period of ten years with effect from July 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,11,816/- suffered by the assessee on the sale of shares of Fort William Jute Company Limited was a loss that arose in its share dealing business.

concepts.interpretation: Loss not in ordinary course if shares bought at premium over market price day after managing agency transfer agreement, large single lot from/to same party, financed by overdraft, treated as investment loss in accounts, stood apart from other dealings.
concepts.unlisted_label: Loss in Ordinary Course of Share Dealing Business
concepts.unlisted_description: Test to determine if share transaction loss deductible as business loss for share dealer assessee.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,11,816/- suffered by the assessee on the sale of shares of Fort William Jute Company Limited was a loss that arose in its share dealing business.

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the loss of Rs. 1,11,816/- suffered by the assessee on the sale of shares of Fort William Jute Company Limited was a loss that arose in its share dealing business.

issues.text: Whether the department was required to obtain a reference on the reasons rejected by the Tribunal for its conclusion in favour of the department.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law on which reference can be made must arise out of the order of the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether it is open to the High Court in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 to embark upon a re-appraisal of the evidence and to arrive at findings of fact contrary to those of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: High Court in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 to embark upon a re-appraisal of the evidence and to arrive at findings of fact contrary to those of the Tribunal.

issues.text: Whether the finding of fact of the Tribunal is defective in law permitting High Court interference.

anchor.surface_text: The finding of fact will be defective in law if there is no evidence to support it or if the finding is unreasonable or perverse

issues.text: Whether in dealing with findings on questions of mixed law and fact, the High Court must accept the findings of the Tribunal on the primary question of fact as final.

anchor.surface_text: in dealing with findings on questions of mixed law and fact, the High Court must accept the findings of the Tribunal on the primary question of fact as final

arguments.claim: The assessee claimed this as a loss arising in the ordinary course of its business.

arguments.court_reasoning: On admitted facts, shares not acquired in ordinary course of business.

arguments.claim: The shares were purchased as a contribution to the scheme of acquisition of the managing agency of the Fort William Jute Co. Ltd. by Mugneeram Bangur Co. or its nominee. The loss, therefore, did not arise in the course of the assessee's normal business of dealing in shares.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner rejected the assessees claim on the ground that the shares were purchased as a contribution to the scheme of acquisition

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal found that there was no evidence that the assessee had been made a pawn in the scheme of acquisition of the managing agency of Fort William Jute Co. Ltd.

arguments.claim: High Court not entitled to reverse Tribunal's findings of fact (no pawn evidence) as department did not challenge via reference; Tribunal partly favoured assessee by reversing ITO/AAC; question general but can't reverse unchallenged findings.

anchor.surface_text: The first contention raised on behalf of the assessee, which is the appellant before us, is that the High Court was not entitled to reverse the findings of fact of the Appellate Tribunal

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ed was framed in the light of the final companyclusion and in our judgment it was number necessary for the department to apply for and obtain a refere

arguments.court_reasoning: Question arises from Tribunal order's final conclusion favouring department; general framing covers it, no need reference on rejected reasons.

arguments.claim: For mixed law/fact questions, Tribunal primary facts final unless perverse/unreasonable/no evidence; HC cannot re-appraise evidence or arrive at contrary facts; did not characterise as perverse; no justification for pawn holding given facts like only 2/4 directors Bangurs, not subsidiary.

anchor.surface_text: It has next been contended on behalf of the appellant that where a question is one of mixed facts and law the facts as found by the Tribunal must be accepted as correct.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ermanner of doubt that the assessee did number acquire the preference shares in the ordinary companyrse of business. These facts may be restated as fo

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts primary facts final but holds application shows not ordinary course on admitted facts.

arguments.claim: Department not required to seek reference on Tribunal-rejected reasons (pawn) since final conclusion favoured department and referred question generally covered conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: The question of law on which reference can be made must arise out of the order of the Tribunal. The order which was made in the present case was in favour of the department

arguments.claim: Even without High Court's pawn conclusion, on admitted/proved facts (market Rs.119 constant to May21, agreement May21, bought May22 at 186/184, sold back same party at 115, overdraft, other dealings small/minimal) irresistible that not acquired in ordinary course of share dealing business.

holdings.text: it was not necessary for the department to apply for and obtain a reference on a question arising from the reasons given by the Tribunal in support of its conclusion in favour of the department.

anchor.surface_text: The question which was referred was framed in the light of the final conclusion and in our judgment it was not necessary for the department to apply for and obtain a reference on a question arising from the reasons given by the Tribunal in support of its conclusion in favour of the department.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Referred question arises out of Tribunal order's final conclusion favouring department; general framing suffices without referencing rejected reasons.

holdings.text: it is not open to the High Court in a reference under s. 66(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1922 to embark upon a re-appraisal of the evidence and to arrive at findings of fact contrary to those of the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: High Court in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act, 1922 to embark upon a re-appraisal of the evidence and to arrive at findings of fact contrary to those of the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court bound by Tribunal fact findings unless lacking evidence, unreasonable, or perverse; follows Greaves Cotton precedent.

holdings.text: in dealing with findings on questions of mixed law and fact, the High Court must accept the findings of the Tribunal on the primary question of fact as final although it is open to the High Court to examine whether the Tribunal had applied the relevant legal principles correctly.

anchor.surface_text: in dealing with findings on questions of mixed law and fact, the High Court must accept the findings of the Tribunal on the primary question of fact as final although it is open to the High Court to examine whether the Tribunal had applied the relevant legal principles correctly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Primary facts final per precedent (Oriental Investment); court reviews legal test application to facts.

holdings.text: In our opinion even if the conclusion of the High Court on the point mentioned above is not taken into consideration the question which was referred had to be answered against the assessee. On admitted and proved facts there can be no manner of doubt that the assessee did not acquire the preference shares in the ordinary course of business.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion even if the conclusion of the High Court on the point mentioned above is not taken into consideration the question which was referred had to be answered against the assessee. On admitted and proved facts there can be no manner of doubt that the assessee did not acquire the preference shares in the ordinary course of business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Disregarding disputed pawn inference, admitted facts (constant market Rs.119 to May 21, bought May 22 at Rs.186, sold back same party at Rs.115, large single lot, overdraft, apart from other dealings) compel conclusion not ordinary course.

holdings.text: The answer to the question must, therefore, be in the negative and against the assessee and it was rightly so returned by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to the question must, therefore, be in the negative and against the assessee and it was rightly so returned by the High Court. The appeal fails and it is dismissed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court; loss not in ordinary course of share dealing business based on extraordinary transaction features.

precedents.cited_proposition: it is number open to the High Court in a reference under s. 66 1 of the Income-tax Act, 1922 to embark upon a re-appraisal of the evidence and to arrive at findings of fact companytrary to those of the Tribunal. Commissioner of Income-tax 2  it has been reiterated that in dealing with findings on questions of mixed law and fact, the High Court must accept the findings of the Tribunal on the primary question of fact as final although it is open to the High Court to examine whether the Tribunal had applied the relevant legal principles companyrectly.
